title: Time's up: MPs set for vote on fate of October 31 Brexit
text:
In two key steps, MPs will first vote to allow a full parliamentary debate on the bill - the so-called "second reading" vote, scheduled for around 5am AEDT.

They will then vote on a motion designed to ram the 110-page bill through all its procedural hoops by the end of Thursday - the only timetable that gives Mr Johnson any sniff of hope that he can pull off an orderly Brexit by October 31.

Mr Johnson will be relying on rebel Labour MPs for support. If he falls short on the second reading vote, he has no way forward for his Brexit deal.

The EU would then offer to delay Brexit, potentially for even more than the requested three months. An election would probably be the only way forward - if Mr Johnson can get MPs to agree to it.

If he gets the second reading vote through but fails to get his debate timetable up, Brexit cannot happen by the end of this month. Mr Johnson would probably pull the legislation and demand an election to break the impasse. Again, there are no iron-clad guarantees he'll get the required votes in parliament to hold an election.

If he gets the second reading vote through and MPs agree to his timetable, he's still not out of the woods. A breakneck debate on amendments to his bill will follow, in which opposition MPs will try to reshape his Brexit deal.

Mr Johnson has warned that any attempt to add riders - such as a second referendum or a customs union covering the whole of Britain - would fundamentally alter his deal. He'd then probably again pull the bill and push for an election.

Even if Mr Johnson does get the bill through in a form he can live with, and keeps his coalition of supportive MPs together, he's then got to power the bill through the House of Lords over the weekend - also a tall order, in a motley chamber given to ponderous proceedings and the odd filibuster.

Parliament is finally at a turning point on Brexit. AP

And even if the does that, he's then got to persuade the European Parliament to reconvene for a special sitting next week - they're currently scheduled to be in recess - and get them to ratify the deal too.

So there's only a single, fragile route to a Halloween Brexit, and at least five points where the Brexit train could derail and push Britain towards a divisive and uncertain election.

It's a bare-knuckle ride ahead. Tonight Mr Johnson finds out if he's even been given a ticket.
description: If MPs back the British PM, he stands a chance of delivering Brexit next week. If not, a delay - and probably an election - looks inevitable.
